page.title: 13HEALTH CARE IN HELPERBY
page.content: {Dr Waud was a General Practioner in {Helperby from 1938 until his {retirement in 1974.He saw many changes {in health care between those years.In {the early years he had a very large {area to look after by himself whereas {now there are four doctors (based at {Boroughbridge) to do the same job. {This was mainly because before the {National Health Service arrived he {needed many patients in order to make {a living. { Dr Waud also felt rather guilty {in,for instance, charging a couple one {guinea (110 pence) for the delivery of {their baby when the father was only {earning 38/6d (Â£1.92\) as a farm {labourer.The National Health Service {was the 'best thing that ever happened {to me' for it gave the Doctor a {guaranteed income for each person {on his 'dispensing list'.}
